FIGURE 5.2 The field lines of (a) a bar magnet, (b) a current-carrying finite solenoid and (c) electric dipole. At large distances, the field lines are very similar. The curves labelled ① and ⑪ are closed Gaussian surfaces.

![img-5.jpeg](images/image_2_5.jpeg)
FIGURE 5.3 Calculation of (a) The axial field of a finite solenoid in order to demonstrate its similarity to that of a bar magnet. (b) A magnetic needle in a uniform magnetic field B. The arrangement may be used to determine either B or the magnetic moment m of the needle.
summary: This text discusses the field lines of a bar magnet, a current-carrying finite solenoid, and an electric dipole. It presents a formula for calculating the axial field of a finite solenoid and explains how a magnetic needle in a uniform magnetic field can be used to determine B or m. The field lines resemble each other at large distances, and the diagram provides examples of various configurations of magnetic field lines.
hypothetical_questions: What is the mathematical formula for calculating the axial field of a finite solenoid?
How can a magnetic needle in a uniform magnetic field be used to determine either B or the magnetic moment m?
How do the field lines of a bar magnet, a current-carrying finite solenoid, and an electric dipole relate at large distances?
What is the importance of understanding the field lines formed by different magnetic configurations?
